menu.aboutText: As of today, the Tashkent Metro — a leading urban transport system in Central Asia — operates over 70 kilometres with 50 stations. In the last quarter of 2024, the daily number of passengers exceeded 1 million.
menu.heading: Passenger Statistics
menu.info: This shows the number of passengers at all Tashkent Metro stations and allows viewing archived data
menu.q1: Where can I purchase an ATTO card and how can I top up the balance?
menu.a1: You can top up your ATTO transport card balance via mobile payment applications such as ATTO, MyUzcard, Payme, Upay, Apelsin, and other electronic payment systems. You can also top up via self-service terminals (infokiosks). The card is available at all sales points of "Toshyulovchitranskhizmat" JSC and "Tashkent Metro".
menu.q2: Where can I contact regarding card issues?
menu.a2: You can call +998 78 140 08 08 or contact via email at info@atto.uz.
menu.q3: If ticket offices are closed at some stations, where can I make a payment?
menu.a3: You can make payments using ATTO, MyUzcard, Payme, Upay, Apelsin, and other mobile payment applications, as well as Paynet terminals.

menu.faq1_question: What is the ATTO transport card?
menu.faq1_answer: The "ATTO" transport card allows you to pay for public transport in Tashkent quickly and conveniently. It is accepted on all buses of the "Toshshahartransxizmat" JSC and at all turnstiles of the "Tashkent Metro" stations.
menu.faq2_question: How can I check the balance on the transport card?
menu.faq2_answer: The balance of the "ATTO" transport card can be checked via ATTO, MyUzcard, Payme, Upay, Apelsin, Click, Oson, Ipak yo'li bank, Alif mobi, Mavrid, Plum, Uzum bank mobile apps, bank infokiosks, or the "Toshshahartransxizmat" JSC and metro ticket offices.
menu.faq3_question: What happens if the balance is less than 1700 UZS?
menu.faq3_answer: If the balance is less than 1700 UZS, the card is temporarily blocked. After topping up, it will be automatically unblocked within 10 minutes. To use it without issues, it is recommended to keep the balance above 1700 UZS.
menu.faq4_question: Can I give my ATTO transport card to someone else?
menu.faq4_answer: No, only one passenger can use an ATTO transport card. For accurate passenger flow statistics, the card cannot be transferred or reused by others. A 6-minute limit is set to prevent accidental repeated payments.
menu.faq5_question: Where can I buy an ATTO card?
menu.faq5_answer: ATTO transport cards are sold at all ticket sales points of "Toshshahartransxizmat" JSC and all "Tashkent Metro" ticket offices.
menu.faq6_question: How can I top up the ATTO transport card?
menu.faq6_answer: The balance of the "ATTO" transport card can be topped up via ATTO, MyUzcard, Payme, Upay, Apelsin, Click, Oson, Ipak yo'li bank, Alif mobi, Mavrid, Plum, Uzum bank mobile apps, and other electronic payment services. It can also be topped up via bank infokiosks and ticket offices.

menu.twelve: All transport payments in one place.
menu.fourteen: Download the app from Google Play and the App Store
menu.sixteen: Enter your phone number and password
menu.eighteen: or open a free virtual card
menu.nineteen: Go to the registration desk at the metro station.
menu.twenty: A staff member will ask you to place your palm above the scanning device. Hold your hand correctly, 15 cm above the device.
menu.twenty_one: First scan your right hand, then your left. After that, a QR code will appear on the screen.
menu.twenty_two: Scan the QR code using the ATTO mobile app. On the home screen, tap "Activate PalmPay" then "Scan QR code".
menu.twenty_three: Check that PalmPay is activated in the ATTO app
menu.twenty_four: Before passing through the turnstile, make sure your linked transport card has sufficient balance. Hold your palm 15 cm above the device
menu.twenty_five: Remove your gloves before entering the turnstile and roll up sleeves so your palm is uncovered
menu.twenty_six: Approach the turnstile with the scanning device
menu.twenty_seven: Place your palm over the scanner and wait for the green light. Once it turns on, proceed through the turnstile
menu.twenty_eight: The fare amount will be deducted from the linked card after a short time
menu.twenty_nine: Pass through and have a safe journey!
menu.thirty_three: This is a fully contactless, innovative way to pay the fare. You no longer need to carry a bank card or take it out of your wallet, as your hand is always with you.
menu.thirty_four: The biometric payment service is not mandatory for all passengers – all other payment methods remain operational.
menu.thirty_five: Paying with your palm is very easy: simply place any palm on the device installed on the turnstile. The turnstile will open and the fare will be deducted from the linked transport card.
menu.forty_three: Tap the FacePay icon for the specified card
menu.forty_four: Check that FacePay is activated in the ATTO app
menu.forty_five: Before passing through the turnstile, ensure your linked transport card has sufficient balance
menu.forty_six: Before passing, remove your headwear and make sure your scarf does not cover your face
menu.forty_seven: Approach the turnstile with a FacePay terminal
menu.forty_eight: The fare amount will be deducted from the linked transport card after a short time
menu.fifty_three: Pay metro fare without a smartphone by scanning your face
menu.fifty_five: This is a fully contactless payment method. You no longer need to touch a smartphone or other surfaces. Biometric payment is not mandatory for all passengers – all other payment methods continue to work.
menu.fifty_six: To use the service, register in the ATTO mobile app, add a photo of your face, and link a transport card with balance. Paying with your face is very easy: approach the turnstile and look at the camera. The turnstile will open and the fare will be deducted from the linked card.
menu.fifty_seven: Available at all stations on the Yunusobod and Chilonzor lines
menu.fifty_eight: Metro fare payment without a smartphone or transport card
menu.sixty_two: These rules define the presence of passengers and other persons in the metro (metro employees, internal affairs officers performing their duties in the metro, and persons visiting the metro with the permission of the metro management), their rights and responsibilities, and the procedure for using the metro.
menu.sixty_four: The following key terms are used in these rules:
menu.sixty_five: station platform — the area for waiting for trains at the station;
menu.sixty_six: ticket — a document confirming a one-time QR-code fare payment for using the metro;
menu.sixty_seven: passenger — a person who has paid the fare or is entitled to a concession and free travel (consumer);
menu.sixty_eight: inspection — a set of measures using special technical means to detect items and substances prohibited for transport and use in order to ensure safety in the metro;
menu.sixty_nine: metro employee — an employee working in the metro and serving passengers (station attendant, train driver, etc.).
menu.seventy_one: A passenger’s presence in the metro and the contract for transporting their luggage is confirmed by a ticket or by showing the relevant documents of persons entitled to concessions and free travel.
menu.seventy_three: Ensures safe and comfortable movement of passengers in the metro.
menu.seventy_five: During movement in the metro, metro employees and passengers must be alert, vigilant, and attentive.
menu.seventy_seven: If suspicious or abandoned items are found on passageways, vestibules, station platforms, or in train cars, metro duty staff or internal affairs officers must be notified.
menu.seventy_eight: Prohibition on tampering with abandoned items
menu.seventy_nine: Any mechanical action on an abandoned item (moving, opening, etc.), changing lighting, temperature, or sound near the item, as well as using radio-electronic devices or communication means nearby is strictly prohibited.
menu.eighty_one: Passengers and other persons must present their luggage for inspection upon lawful request of internal affairs officers. Persons suspected of carrying prohibited items or behaving suspiciously may be inspected in accordance with legislation.
menu.eighty_three: In emergencies that pose a threat to life and health, passengers are evacuated from the station or to the adjacent station on the train, following instructions of metro staff.
menu.eighty_five: In case of malfunctions in trains or other equipment, passengers are transported to stations using single-track or bi-directional movement depending on the situation.
menu.eighty_seven: In case of malfunctions of technical means affecting safety on stations or above-ground paths, metro staff take measures to safely evacuate passengers through tunnels and overpasses.
menu.eighty_nine: Passengers have the following rights when using the metro:
menu.ninety: to carry children under seven years old, as well as strollers for children and persons with disabilities, free of charge;
menu.ninety_one: persons with disabilities and limited mobility may use metro technical facilities;
menu.ninety_two: to take amateur photos and videos at stations;
menu.ninety_three: to use medical points located at stations;
menu.ninety_four: to use telephone and communication devices.
menu.ninety_six: Passengers have the following responsibilities when using the metro:
menu.ninety_seven: to comply with public order, sanitary and hygiene standards and rules;
menu.ninety_eight: to pay the fare in accordance with legislative acts;
menu.ninety_nine: to have the ticket ready when approaching passage points;
menu.one_hundred: to follow safety rules on escalators;
menu.one_hundred_three: Metro employees have the following rights:
menu.one_hundred_four: to check all documents granting free travel;
menu.one_hundred_six: to require passengers not to damage metro equipment;
menu.one_hundred_seven: to use the metro for free while performing official duties.
menu.one_hundred_nine: Metro employees have the following responsibilities:
menu.one_hundred_ten: to receive and dispatch metro trains;
menu.one_hundred_eleven: to ensure compliance with train schedules;
menu.one_hundred_twelve: to wear the prescribed uniform during service;
menu.one_hundred_thirteen: to inform passengers to be careful and attentive;
menu.one_hundred_fourteen: to organize evacuation procedures in emergencies.
menu.one_hundred_sixteen: Disputes arising from the application of these rules are resolved in accordance with legislative acts.
menu.one_hundred_eighteen: Persons guilty of violating these rules shall be held liable in accordance with legislative acts.
menu.one_hundred_twenty: Resolution of the Cabinet of Ministers of the Republic of Uzbekistan

menu.one_hundred_thirty_five: State Flag of the Republic of Uzbekistan

menu.one_hundred_thirty_seven: Adopted at the extraordinary session of the Supreme Council of the Republic of Uzbekistan on November 18, 1991.
menu.one_hundred_thirty_nine: Symbol of the sky and water, beauty of nature, source of life, and peace.
menu.one_hundred_forty_one: Symbol of nature's renewal, spring and hope, and the people's aspiration for prosperity.
menu.one_hundred_forty_three: Symbol of purity and honesty, peace, and tranquility.
menu.one_hundred_forty_five: The vital force pulsing through every living being, a symbol of life.
menu.one_hundred_forty_seven: A traditional symbol of the Uzbek people. The crescent represents renewal; the 12 stars represent the months of the year and the ancient zodiac.
menu.one_hundred_forty_nine: State Emblem of the Republic of Uzbekistan
menu.one_hundred_fifty: Law "On the State Emblem of the Republic of Uzbekistan"
menu.one_hundred_fifty_one: Adopted at the 10th session of the Supreme Council of the Republic of Uzbekistan on July 2, 1992.
menu.one_hundred_fifty_three: The emblem depicts the sun shining over a blooming valley.
menu.one_hundred_fifty_five: On the left are wheat ears; on the right, blooming cotton bolls.
menu.one_hundred_fifty_seven: At the top of the emblem is an eight-pointed star symbolizing the unity of the republic: inside the star are the crescent and star, sacred symbols for Muslims.
menu.one_hundred_fifty_nine: In the center of the emblem is the legendary Humo bird, a symbol of courage, nobility, and devotion. These symbols reflect the people's aspirations for peace, goodness, happiness, and prosperity.
menu.one_hundred_sixty_one: At the bottom of the emblem, on the ribbon representing the State Flag of the Republic, "Uzbekistan" is written.
menu.one_hundred_sixty_three: State Anthem of the Republic of Uzbekistan
menu.one_hundred_sixty_six: The text and music of the State Anthem of the Republic of Uzbekistan are approved by the Law of the Republic of Uzbekistan dated December 10, 1992, No. 768-XII "On the State Anthem of the Republic of Uzbekistan".

menu.two_hundred_sixty_two: The Chilonzor line is the first operating metro line, running from Buyuk Ipak Yo'li station to Chinor station
menu.two_hundred_sixty_eight: The Uzbekistan line is the second operating line, running from Beruniy station to Do‘stlik station
menu.two_hundred_seventy_four: The Yunusabad line is the third operating metro line, running from Turkiston station to Mingorik station
menu.two_hundred_eighty: The above-ground circular line is the fourth operating line, from Technopark station to Qipchoq station
menu.two_hundred_eighty_six: The first and only metro system in Central Asia has begun construction
menu.two_hundred_eighty_nine: On November 6, 1977, from Olmazor station to Amir Temur xiyoboni station, the Chilonzor electro-depot complex and communication building were put into operation
menu.two_hundred_ninety_two: Length 4.2 km, from Amir Temur xiyoboni station to Buyuk ipak yo‘li station, 3 stations were opened in August 1980. After these stations, Chilonzor metro line construction extended from southwest to northeast through city center with 12 stations and total length 16.3 km
menu.two_hundred_ninety_five: From Alisher Navoi station to Toshkent station, length over 5.6 km connecting city center to railway station, 5 stations opened on November 26, 1984
menu.two_hundred_ninety_eight: Length over 3.2 km, Toshkent, Mashinasozlar, Do‘stlik stations opened in 1987
menu.three_hundred_one: Length over 2.2 km, from Alisher Navoi station to Chorsu station, 2 stations opened in 1989
menu.three_hundred_four: 3.2 km from Chorsu station to Beruniy station, total 11 stations and Uzbekistan electro-depot included
menu.three_hundred_seven: To improve transport service for city residents, on October 26, 2001, the section from Ming ‘orik station to Shahriston station, total length 7.15 km with 6 stations, was put into operation
menu.three_hundred_ten: In 2016, the President of Uzbekistan Sh.M. Mirziyoyev signed a series of decrees to continue metro construction. According to the President's decree on November 7, 2016, 'On measures to implement the second phase of the Yunusobod line of Tashkent Metro' PQ-2653, construction of two stations 'Turkiston' and 'Yunusobod' with a length of 2.9 km began. In August 2020, these stations were put into operation. Currently, the total length of the Yunusobod line is 9.5 km with 8 stations, connecting a large residential area to the city center.
menu.three_hundred_thirteen: According to the President of Uzbekistan's decree on May 19, 2017, PQ-2979, the project for constructing an above-ground circular metro line in Tashkent is being implemented.
menu.three_hundred_fifteen: In August 2020, the 1st phase of the above-ground circular metro line – 11.5 km with 7 stations – was put into operation. To implement these decisions, in 2020 a total of 14 new metro sections and stations with a total length of 21.4 km were built and commissioned.
menu.three_hundred_eighteen: According to the President of Uzbekistan's decree on November 29, 2016, PQ-2664, for implementing the Sergeli line project, in December 2020, 5 stations of the new 7.0 km Sergeli metro line were built and commissioned.
menu.three_hundred_thirty_five: The first, safe, convenient, and fast public transport in Central Asia, operating since 1977.
menu.three_hundred_thirty_seven: Metro lines serving Tashkent city and interconnected
menu.three_hundred_forty_two: From foundation to modern expansion - continuous growth and innovation.
menu.three_hundred_forty_four: Today, the Tashkent Metro is a leading urban transport system in Central Asia, with over 70 kilometers in length and 50 stations. By the last quarter of 2024, the daily passenger count exceeded 1 million.
menu.three_hundred_fifty_two: Head of 'Tashkent Metro' State Unitary Enterprise
menu.three_hundred_fifty_three: 3rd and 4th weeks of the month, Thursday
menu.three_hundred_fifty_four: Born in 1960 in Tashkent. Higher education. In 1982 graduated from Tashkent Automobile Roads Institute as an engineer for automobile transport operation. Started work at Tashkent 1-Avtokorxona, later held various managerial positions. 2003–2005 — Hokim of Yakkasaroy district, 2005–2012 — Deputy Hokim of Tashkent city, 2012–2018 — Hokim of Tashkent city. Since 2021 — Head of 'Tashkent Metro' SUE. Awarded 'For Labor Glory' in 2008 and 'For Dedicated Service' in 2024.
menu.three_hundred_sixty: Chuqursoy station, Tashkent Railway. 2018–2018 — Keles station switch operator, 3346 km. 2018–2019 — chief specialist of Yunusobod District Investment Complex secretariat. 2019–2019 — Deputy Head of Investment and Foreign Trade Department, Yunusobod district. 2019–2021 — chief specialist of Yunusobod District Investment Complex secretariat. 2021–2021 — Deputy Head of Transport Organization Service, Tashkent Metro. 2022–2024 — manager of Tashkent Metro SUE. Since 2024 — Chief Engineer of Tashkent Metro SUE.
menu.three_hundred_sixty_four: Deputy Head of the Tashkent Metro for Security
menu.three_hundred_sixty_six: 2019–2022 – Deputy Head of the Tashkent Metro for Security. Since 2022 – currently holds the same position.
menu.three_hundred_seventy: Deputy Head of the Tashkent Metro
menu.three_hundred_seventy_two: Born in 1988 in Tashkent region. Higher education. In 2015 graduated from the Tashkent Financial Institute with a degree in taxation. Began his career 2009–2011 as chief accountant of the Finance Department of the S. Rakhimov district administration of Tashkent. 2011–2013 – Deputy Head of Finance Department of Almazar district – Head of the “Budget control” department; 2013–2018 – Head of Finance Department of Almazar district; 2018–2019 – Head of the “Staff and special works” department of the Tashkent City Finance Office; 2019–2024 – Head of Finance Department of Shaykhontohur district; 2024–2025 – Chief of a department in the Tashkent City Economy and Finance Department; 2025 – Director of “Inson” social services center in Shaykhontohur; Since 2025 – Deputy Head of the Tashkent Metro.
menu.three_hundred_seventy_five: Deputy Head of the Tashkent Metro for Marketing
menu.three_hundred_seventy_seven: Born in 1985 in Syrdarya Region. Higher education. In 2008 graduated from the Tashkent Institute of Irrigation and Melioration in Management. Began his career in 2002 as a specialist at the multipurpose information center of Marokand LLC. 2004–2008 – Student; 2011–2014 – Director of “Agro-nektar”; 2014–2015 – Inspector then Chief Accountant of the Pension Fund in Shaykhontohur district; 2015–2016 – Leading specialist in Tashkent City Mayor’s Office; 2016–2017 – Leading specialist in industry development; 2017–2018 – Leading then chief specialist in Industry Development Department; 2018 – Chief ICT specialist at the Automobile Transport Agency; 2018–2019 – Assistant to Yunusabad district mayor; 2019–2021 – Head of administration of Yunusabad district; 2021 – Head of Permits Department at Ministry of Transport; Since 2021 – Deputy Head for Marketing at Tashkent Metro.
menu.three_hundred_eighty_one: Acting Deputy Head of Tashkent Metro for Construction
menu.three_hundred_eighty_three: Started his career in 1995 as a clerk at the General Prosecutor's Office of the Republic. Studied at the Plekhanov Russian University of Economics in 1996–2000. Worked as an economist, investigator, director, and lawyer in various public and private organizations. Served as Head of Housing and Communal Services Department of Shaykhontohur District Hokimiyat in 2019–2023, and Deputy Hokim for Construction and Ecology in 2023–2024. Since 2024 — Deputy Hokim of Yakkasaray District for Landscaping.
menu.three_hundred_eighty_seven: Deputy Head of Tashkent Metro for Scientific and Innovative Development — Vice-Rector of the Transport University
menu.three_hundred_eighty_nine: Born in 1990 in Uzun, Surkhandarya region. Higher education. Graduated from Railway College (2008), Tashkent Institute of Railway Engineers (2015), Tashkent State University of Economics (2018), and Higher School of Business and Entrepreneurship under the Cabinet of Ministers (2022, Project Management). Began career in railway sector, held various management positions. Previously Director of the Railway Workers Training Center under the Ministry of Transport. Currently Deputy Head of Tashkent Metro for Scientific and Innovative Development.
menu.three_hundred_ninety_three: Deputy Head of Tashkent Metro — Chief Inspector for Traffic Safety
menu.three_hundred_ninety_five: Higher education. Bachelor’s (2014) and Master’s (2016) degrees from Tashkent Institute of Railway Engineering. Graduated from the Academy of Public Administration under the President of Uzbekistan in 2019. Previously Deputy Chief Engineer of Tashkent Metro for Ground Line Operations.

menu.four_hundred_eighty_five: Strategy for ensuring gender equality in our country
menu.four_hundred_eighty_six: As a result of our large-scale measures for political, social, and economic modernization, a new Uzbekistan is taking shape
menu.four_hundred_eighty_eight: As a result of our large-scale measures for political, social, and economic modernization, a new Uzbekistan is taking shape. Today, democratic changes in our country have become irreversible.
menu.four_hundred_eighty_nine: Last year's parliamentary elections demonstrated increased political activity of the population and parties, the role of civil society institutions, and the influence of mass media. Gender equality policy has become a priority for us. The role of women in government is steadily growing.
menu.four_hundred_ninety: In our new Parliament, the number of female deputies has doubled. The human rights situation has completely changed. Forced and child labor has been fully eliminated. A National Human Rights Strategy has been adopted.
menu.four_hundred_ninety_one: In response to the UN's call to reduce statelessness, 50 thousand of our fellow citizens were granted Uzbek citizenship this year. The situation regarding religious freedom in our country has also significantly improved.
menu.four_hundred_ninety_two: Strengthening interethnic and interfaith tolerance remains a constant important task for us
menu.four_hundred_ninety_six: Start your career in our team
